awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: PPoSS: Planning: Principles for Edge Sensing and Computing for Personalized, Precision Healthcare at National Scale
awd_abstract_narration:
Personalized, precision healthcare (PPH) utilizing edge sensing-computing can collect, analyze and interpret continuous, multi-modality data, both physical and physiologic, producing information, knowledge and insight needed for real-time disease onset and progression monitoring at both the individual and population levels. This planning proposal will (i) identify the challenges and investigate the principles and potential solutions for the edge sensing-computing paradigm; (ii) engage diverse academic, community and government stakeholders to collectively define the functional and performance requirements for PPH; and (iii) create and validate preliminary approaches and devise a concrete, detailed plan for scaling PPH to national levels. It is well aligned with NSF’s mission to  “advance the national health, prosperity and welfare.” This project can generate enormous social and economic benefits for communities, healthcare systems, and other stakeholders. If successful, the project will enable the monitoring of epidemics (e.g. disease outbreaks/spread, early detection/preemptive intervention of acute/infectious diseases) and the management of chronic physical and psychological conditions. The PIs will 1) disseminate publications, data and systems in academic, industry and community venues; 2) integrate CISE student education (including female and under-represented minorities) at different levels; 3) mentor high-school students on joint health-technology research; 4) cultivate a technology-literate healthcare workforce; and 5) pilot the technologies for immediate benefits to nearby communities while  studying how to scale to other rural, suburban, and city settings.

This project will explore, design, and evaluate potential solutions for enhancing the scalability of edge sensing-computing-based PPH in four dimensions of different types of sensing data, analytic algorithms, diseases, health conditions,  and population sizes. The PIs will identify challenges and validate approaches guided by three principles: privacy as a first-class citizen, design for faults and exploitation of scale. The team will: 1) define new abstractions and quantifiable metrics for end-to-end security and privacy guarantees across hardware, software and application stack; 2) investigate systems for multi-temporal resolution processing of heterogeneous healthcare data, incorporating composition of components from possibly untrusted third parties and accommodate noises, disturbances or even adversary-controlled data; 3) explore novel AI/machine-learning algorithms suitable for PPH learning and inference, including AutoML for neural-network architecture search, model compression and federated learning at extreme scale while meeting security, privacy and robustness constraints; and 4) develop heterogeneous hardware accelerators and general design methodologies and tools for neural-hardware architecture co-design, efficient acceleration for time-series, point-cloud and language/sound understanding, and on-device edge training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rich varieties of edge sensing devices are expected to reach 10-100 per person in the next decade and produce unprecedented continuous, heterogeneous data at one to two orders of magnitude higher volume, enabling numerous novel applications. Personalized, precision healthcare (PPH) utilizing edge sensing and computing at national levels is arguably the top application that can benefit our society. It can collect, analyze and interpret continuous, multi-modality data, both physical and physiologic, at multitemporal resolutions, producing information, knowledge and insight needed for real time disease onset and progression monitoring at both the individual and population levels. By recognizing symptoms such as respiratory distress and elevated body temperature, or detecting phenomena of social crowding, PPH can monitor and predict the spatial-temporal propagation of an epidemic (e.g., COVID-19, flu), enable early detection and preemptive intervention (e.g., Alzheimer's, Parkinson's), and provide guidance for managing chronic physical and psychological conditions (e.g., diabetes, asthma, anxiety).

Under this planning project, we have further generalized the above ideas into creating a new discipline of "computational screening and surveillance" (CSS) that uses modern sensing and AI/ML techniques for the early detection and continuous monitoring of a broad spectrum of diseases and health conditions. The CSS sensing and learning infrastructure, when developed, can be applicable to many health conditions each costing billions of dollars to the healthcare system (e.g., diabetes, congestive heart failures). Continuous collection and real time learning from rich physiological and physical data can detect the early onset of diseases, monitor the effectiveness of treatment and medication, enable preemptive intervention and timely adjustment that can greatly improve the quality, effectiveness and costs of care.

Specifically, we have identified the challenges and investigated the principles and potential solutions in four areas of privacy, systems, algorithms and architecture for the learning infrastructure of CSS. We have formed a team of four institutions including Stony Brook, MIT, Rutgers and Penn State with expertise in the above four areas to chart out the vision and big picture of developing CSS technologies, the major technical directions, problems and potential approaches.

We have engaged diverse academic, community and government organizations to collectively define the functional and performance requirements for CSS. These included our Health Advisory Board members, providers at Stony Brook Hospital with backgrounds and expertise in long-COVID, preventive medicine, family medicine, primary care, gerontology, cardio-pulmonary diseases, sleep, cardiology, and biostatistics. We have held discussions with providers in neurology, occupational and physical therapy, and experts in falls prevention, hearing and vision loss, long term care facilities for older adults.

We have created, validated some preliminary approaches, methods and developed a concrete, detailed, and successful large proposal for developing the systems, solutions and tools for CSS. The investigation covered some of most basic and fundamental building blocks needed in CSS. These included: robust vital sign measurement methods from radio signals leveraging both classical and deep learning techniques to handle errors caused by disruptions from body motions; the roles, benefits and functions continuous sensing may offer to the management of the various symptoms in long-COVID patients; the basic structure of a three-tier infrastructure consisting of sensing nodes producing continuous data, edge servers that aggregate and analyze such data at home, and cloud backend that controls the operations of sensing and edge nodes, and aggregate data for more powerful and general analytics.

The planning project has produced 6 peer reviewed publications disseminated broadly in the research community. The three-tier infrastructure is undergoing testing in the context of the subsequent large grant. The robust vital sign extraction methods are built into the sensing part of the infrastructure. The team has had expansive and successful discussions with more partners who are strongly interested in deploying the technologies for real patients. The project has provided full or partial support and training for 5 Ph.D. students, 1 M.D./MPH student, and 1 undergraduate student.
